The KULGMARK dwarves submit to these curses to atone for the immorality of dwarf-folk in general.

faction.clocks: Create a horde of slaves to rid the tribe of evils (internally and externally) once and for all.

[this is actually from a sourcebook]
"In fact, many gnoll tribes have “tantekurash” or “spirit breakers” who are experts at breaking the wills of slaves. If the slave resists, he/she is eaten. Occasionally a slave’s mind becomes so broken they revere the brutality of their gnoll captors. They then become “kryshantel” or “savage souls” who follow their gnoll masters into battle as thralls. 
(take out the slave stuff, and make these spirit breakers use cthulhu stuff … and there’s the evil guy doing it.)"

work.title: [Nicklefurrow ms]
work.contents: I returned to northeast Nicklefurrow where the thief, Bergna, by all accounts a greatly disfigured creature, stooped and scarred, was last seen. Prostrating myself in ritual abnegation, I dove into the seething whirlwind of jukas, the roiling signs left by the unsatisfied spirits who had passed by. A jagged promontory stabbed upwards out of the otherwise placid web; unmistakably, this was the chasm which that splinter of Sirmgalv carved through the tapestry of ghostly mundanity. Its frantic outline led unerringly south, seeking the great leuqline which unites the islands and makes landfall in Nicklefurrow. Near the north-west elbow of the leuqline the spear's fulgurous spoor sunk precipitously into the ground and out of sight. Confident I could mirror its path, I released myself from the ritual's grasp, but the sere afterimage of that ungodly weapon marched across my vision, and I took slow and uncertain steps south.

work.title: Commentary on the Diaschizdein Glaucous

Xorn scour the depths of the earth for precious metal and stones. Because they are unable to consume organic material, they ignore most other creatures. However, a xorn's ability to sniff out metals and stones often draws its attention to adventurers carrying coins and gems. Because a xorn isn't evil, it pleads or bargains in the hope of convincing owners to give up their treasure, offering up information it has learned from its travels in exchange. A xorn whose requests are ignored might resort to threats and bullying. If starving or angered, it resorts to force.

bible.name: Zorbon gravity orb
bible.short description:
Edible, uncommon
The orb is about six inches in diameter and constructed of a lustrous, metallic black substance. When held in the hand it changes size to fit comfortably in the palm. If you attempt to consume the orb, it shrinks to the size of a small berry relative to your size. After consumption, your speed drops to 1, you cannot become prone, and you have +5 to any Acrobatics checks made. The effect lasts for one munte, after which the orb is ejected from the creature’s preferred orifice. Consuming takes one action. The effect can be ended at any time by using a bonus action. This effect can be used once per day per creature (resetting at dawn). It time a creature uses it in a day beyond that first use, their Constitution drops by 3. Constitution points lost in this way cannot be healed with magic and are regained at the next dawn.

entries: The band of adventurers, having expelled von Veen's spirit from Uugeet, discovered that their victory coincided fortuitously with the celebration of Raising the Pendulum Bob which simultaned [coincided] that year with Braggot Day in the gnome town of Briangle. Drav customed [visited] the local post office branch to ship a frosty bottle of trollsmilk and an extensive missive to her family in Forest Ogrelodge. Fez, always perfectly in touch with his inner springwork, was motivated to call forth a steadfast steed. Tregetting [juggling] for inspiration a piece of coral bestowed to him under miraculous circumstances, he attracted the attention of a sloppy clown named Kuma who led him to a park pond swarming with cave turtles from which the ecologically irresponsible jape gathered a healthy supply of eggrocks. Meanwhile, Carlos, having glutted his mouth and purse with vendible candies which could have been purloined for free from the Candy Lab, gawked at The Unwieldy Dolphin's shingle and forthnimmed [proceeded, lit. 'go away, go forth'] to a desecrated former shrine to Aulë being used as a social club. He attempted to preach the good word to the finger-sandwich-eating, real-estate-discussing philistines, but, unable to convert any of the nonbelievers, satisfied himself with carving a statuette of Aulë into the rock wall and distributing prayer books with Drav's help. While Paros won himself a manuary [(prob.) pardon] from the local villagers to free the pendulum bob from its hempen restraints and return quasi-time to the town, Flick took a moment to recall sifting some poudree [medicinal powder] from Uugeet's pool before samming up [gathering] the party and making for the surface with Domonkos.

Achieving externity [(prob.) coming to the surface] on The Grey Tongue, all but Carlos and Flick were taken unawares by two shapeless black muckhumps calling themselves Naphula and Gluðer who, drawn by Drav's demon skinprint, attempted to incaptivate [capture] and dissolve the dwarven wizard. After unceremoniously roasting Gluðer, the party danced around serving up Naphula in the same way until Drav could be safely extracted and Flick, amused by the ooze, could invite Naphula to confederate with them. The super-lemure having been cindered, Paros scooped some ash at the behest of Veenock and then went to get some ass with Domonkos, making it to vampire-second-but-human-third?-base, all the while chaperoned by trigger-low-affect Flick. Rather than spending the night in the woods, everyone vamoosed behind the vampire to the castle, making for the single lit room high in the central palace. The tricky little spellbook Drav snatched from Riult took one last leap at manumission and inconveniently revealed their position, but it seemed to matter not, as who should await them in the bedroom chamber but one calling herself Lupenna; and, as if that were not enough, she recognized Flick!

items.name: Braggot Day
entries: A festival in Briangle during which braggot — a mixture of ale, mead, and spices — is imbibed. Oftentimes its celebration coincides with the autumnal event Raising the Pendulum Bob.

entries: While Fez and Flick sunk into a quiet sloom [doze], Carlos, Drav, Paros, and Joan tied up a few loose ends. Carlos helpfully speculated that 'maybe Juniper came from a meat-person that wore the mask, and Juniper laid a meat-egg, and then Juniper was inside the meat-egg.' Further afrayning [questioning] prompted Ethel to pontificate on the 'ancient ways of the Three School' and Juniper's particular interest in the mysteries of life and death. All matters resolved, the gang turned their attentions to ••; Drav determined that the blurry symbols decorating ••'s shell were lexemes in an old language used by artificers, and Paros unintentionally presented the tremulous box with visions of evisceration. Before much else could go wrong, /, a construct isometric to ••, hailed the group and led them to Red Fox University. Passing through a cozy common room inhabited by Briffa and Reginald, two teenful [annoyed; cognate with Old Saxon tiono crime, injustice, injury] students, and a sleepy xorn named Turkey, where they learned that •• had been running away from an emotionally volatile love triangle with – and - (siblings, no less!). Joan smashed down some doors to track the still fleeing / who brought them ultimately to Sik's alchemical workshop, where •• received some much-needed relaxation and reprogramming. After smoking a bit of laced leaf, Sik showed Joan how to turn her multicolored stone into a floating force field and pointed them towards Professor Henriette Erman who, aside from studying for a license to practice psychiatric medicine, schooled them on the ancient mountain deity Karnish and the primordial provenance of the various Three Schools which roam the land. Finally, they were pointed to Ymenestra, a visiting lecturer with a personal and professional interest in depossessions and exorcisms.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: Samai's spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 16}). She can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

action.name: Pseudopod
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d8 + 6}) bludgeoning damage plus 9 ({@damage 2d8}) poison damage.

action.name: Memory Spores
entries: Samai releases spores that burst out in a cloud that fills a 20-foot-radius sphere centered on her, and it lingers for 1 minute. Any flesh-and-blood creature in the cloud when it appears, or that enters it later, must make a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the creature inherits one or more of Samai's fragmented memories, which may reveal information about Samai or comingle with its own knowledge and reveal truths or falsehoods about itself.

action.name: Mind Control Spores
entries: Samai releases spores that burst out in a cloud that fills a 20-foot-radius sphere centered on her. Humanoids and beasts in the cloud when it appears must make a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is {@condition charmed} by her until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Euphoria Spores
entries: Samai releases a cloud of spores in a 20-foot-radius sphere centered on itself. Other creatures in that area must each succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or become diseased until the end of their next turn. A creature {@condition poisoned} in this way A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect early on itself on a success. When the effect ends on it, the creature gains one level of {@condition exhaustion}.

action.name: Photophobia Spores
entries: Samai releases a cloud of spores in a 20-foot-radius sphere centered on itself. Other creatures in that area must each succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw. On a successful save, the creature can't be infected by these spores for 24 hours. On a failed save, for 1 minute, while the creature is in sunlight, the creature has disadvantage on ability checks, attack rolls, and saving throws. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect early on itself on a success. Once infected, a creature can't be reinfected by these spores.

reaction.name: Protective Shriek
entries: When Samai is hit by an attack, one creature that is {@condition charmed} by her must use its reaction to emit a shriek audible within 300 feet of it. The creature continues to shriek until the end of its next turn.

entries.name: Zuggtmoy
entries: The Demon Queen of Fungi, Lady of Rot and Decay, Zuggtmoy is an alien creature whose only desire is to infect the living with spores, transforming them into her mindless servants and, eventually, into decomposing hosts for the mushrooms, molds, and other fungi that she spawns.

Utterly inhuman, Zuggtmoy can mold her fungoid form into an approximation of a humanoid shape, including the skeletal-thin figure depicted in grimoires and ancient art, draped and veiled in mycelia and lichen. Indeed, much of her appearance and manner, and that of her servants, is a soulless mockery of mortal life and its many facets.

Zuggtmoy's cultists often follow her unwittingly. Most are fungi—infected to some degree, whether through inhaling her mind-controlling spores or being transformed to the point where flesh and fungus become one. Such cultists are fungal extensions of the Demon Queen's will.
Their devotion might begin with the seemingly harmless promises offered by exotic spores and mushrooms, but quickly consumes them, body and soul.
